description:
Amphibacillus marinus is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Amphibacillus. It is a Gram-positive, facultatively anaerobic, spore-forming bacterium that was isolated from seawater collected from the Yellow Sea in China.

The cells of Amphibacillus marinus are rod-shaped, motile, and measure approximately 0.3-0.5 μm in width and 1.0-3.0 μm in length. The bacterium is capable of growing in a wide range of salinities, from 0.5% to 10% NaCl, and can tolerate temperatures from 10°C to 45°C, with an optimal growth temperature of 30-37°C.

Amphibacillus marinus is capable of utilizing a variety of carbohydrates, including glucose, fructose, sucrose, and maltose, as carbon and energy sources. It can also reduce nitrate to nitrite and produce catalase and oxidase enzymes.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences has shown that Amphibacillus marinus is closely related to other members of the genus Amphibacillus, which are commonly found in marine and estuarine environments.

The ecological role and potential applications of Amphibacillus marinus in various biotechnological or environmental processes are still under investigation.
